text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with english muffins
that's right i'm going to show you my
totally not traditional no need method
for making english muffins in this
particular video was inspired by one of
my favorite shows you know the one where
the celebrity foodies kind of sit around
discussing the best things they've ever
eaten but anyway I saw an English muffin
featured on that show that looks so
amazing I had to give it a try
and while I didn't end up using their
exact recipe this still came out very
good and was basically one package of
artisan corn meal away from being
perfect but we'll get into my cornmeal
issues later for now let's go ahead and
get started with the dough and the first
step for me is making sure my yeast is
alive so I'm going to dump that into a
mixing bowl along with a little bit of
our flour and some warm water and what I
do is I mix that up and I wait about ten
minutes to see if my yeast is active and
to be honest with modern quick-acting
East this is probably a completely
unnecessary step but I'm old-fashioned
so I like to wait about ten minutes and
if a thin layer of foam starts to form
on the top I know my yeast is good and
because I only waited about ten minutes
it's not super easy to see if you waited
15 or 20 minutes it would be much more
obvious but I could tell mine was active
so we're going to continue on with the
rest of the ingredients so we're going
to go ahead and drizzle in a little bit
of vegetable oil as well as a nice big
pinch of kosher salt and then for a
little bit of protein we're going to add
one egg white which is hopefully going
to help give our English muffins a
little extra chewiness so just the white
will save the yolk hey maybe you could
make some aioli with that it's not a bad
idea and then we'll finish off with the
rest of our flour and I'm just using
all-purpose here as well as the rest of
our warm water so at this point what
we'll do is we'll take a sturdy wooden
spoon and start mixing this up so as I
mentioned this is a no need recipe and
after a few minutes of mixing we're
going to end up with a very wet very
sticky dough which by the way would be
virtually impossible to knead even if we
wanted to but we don't so at this point
we're going to stop we'll clean off our
spoon we'll scrape down the sides the
best we can and then all we're going to
do is cover this and set it in some
relatively warm spot for a couple hours
or until it doubles in size and I'm
gonna use my oven which has a proofing
feature which keeps the temp about
seventy-five to
these but really any draft-free kind of
warm spots going to work and like I said
we'll leave that in there for a couple
hours and if everything's gone according
to plan it should look like this
so you can see here it's very bubbly
almost batter like and we'll give that a
stir and kind of knock everything down
at which point we will transfer that
onto an extremely well floured surface
because what we're going to have to do
here is knead in a little bit of flour
so we can actually work with this stuff
because like I said and like you can see
it's extremely sticky and wet so we'll
flour our surface well and we'll add
some more flour to the top and we'll
give this a very brief kneading maybe
about a minute working in just enough
flour so we can get our dough ball to
the point where we can effectively cut
it into six equal pieces and if you're
thinking hey I thought you said this was
no need it is this doesn't count come on
it's like a minute and by the way this
recipe is perfect for practicing working
with difficult dough's okay people don't
like working with sticky dough's because
they're annoying and they get frustrated
and they end up adding too much flour
which for many kind of breads and things
like pizza dough is a fatal flaw so not
only are you going to get some decent
English muffins out of this recipe I
actually think it's going to raise your
dough making game so like I said we're
just going to work in enough flour so
that we're able to just barely handle it
and we'll form that into some kind any
kind of uniform shape and then we'll
take our bench scraper and cut this into
six pieces and it's not a bad idea to
flour that bench scraper also so we'll
go ahead and cut that in half and then
each of those halves in the three and
then once our dough has been portioned
we need to roll these pieces of dough
into a ball that has no seams which with
very sticky dough is not that easy so
here's how we're going to do that we're
going to cut our hand over the dough
ball and by using a circular motion
where we keep our fingertips inside of
our thumb on the table and we basically
use our palm and the friction from the
table to form which should be a seamless
ball of dough and if you use too much
flour it's not going to be tacky enough
to stick to the table yet if it's too
wet it'll just smear on the table so
right here I'm going to add another
pinch and then we will cut our hand over
it again and eventually what should form
is a perfectly seamless ball of dough
and if you get it on your first try you
will be the first cook in history so
this is going to take a little bit of
practice but you'll get it trust me
and once we have those perfect seamless
dough balls formed we will transfer
those onto a cornmeal lined baking sheet
and we do on both sides of our dough to
be coated with cornmeal and for some
reason I bought this fancy overpriced
artisan brand which was basically a
combination of powdered fine cornmeal
and giant chunks of cornmeal and it
doesn't really look like a big deal here
but I didn't like the appearance when I
cooked these so long story short I was
screwed over by some hipster cornmeal
but anyway enough complaining I'm sure
some of you have actual problems so
we'll transfer our dough onto our baking
sheet and kind of press it down a little
doing our best to coat both sides and
then what we need to do as usual is let
these double in size before we cook them
so I'm going to place those back in the
oven which again is not on it's just on
the proof setting and leave those in
there for about an hour to an hour and a
half or two like I said they double in
size at which point they should look
something like this
and once that's happened we can go ahead
and cook these up and how we're going to
do that is in clarified butter so I'm
going to add a generous amount to a
cast-iron skillet set over medium heat
and when that heats up we're going to
carefully carefully transfer our dough
into the pan
try not to deflate it too much and then
all we're going to do is give those
about seven minutes per side or until
they're cooked through and normally I'm
in a pretty good mood when I'm watching
stuff cooking butter but all I could do
is stare at that uneven cornmeal I know
I said it was going to stop complaining
but what we really should have here is
an even uniform coating of cornmeal
going all the way across the surface and
not just a few big chunks here and there
but anyway seriously I'm going to let it
go now I've heard that stressing about
things like that can cause hair loss and
that's the last thing I need so I gave
that first side about five or six
minutes and then flipped him over and
gave the other side about the same and
then I just started playing with them
kind of flipping them over randomly
trying to get the level of brownies to
sort of match but bottom line both sides
cooked approximately seven or eight
minutes which for this size should be
enough to cook them through and once
those are done we want to remove those
to a baking rack to cool completely
don't even think of tearing into these
while they're warm trust me it won't be
any good okay we really need that
residual heat inside to finish the
cooking so I let mine cool
and then I lined him up on a plate and I
had what appeared to be some very
nice-looking English muffins the color
was pretty close the shape was very
close and they seemed to be just about
the right thickness but appearances can
be deceiving and there's only one real
way to know if you've made a successful
English muffin and that is to split it
open and as far as an English muffin
goes there is only one approved method
to do that we're going to go all the way
around with a fork and then tear it open
only a crazy person uses a knife on an
English muffin and you're probably
thinking hey I use a knife and I'm not
crazy yeah you are you just don't know
it that's one of the main problems with
being crazy so we're gonna use a fork
and go all the way around at which point
we can tear it open revealing what are
hopefully tons of nooks and crannies so
that is looking just about perfect and
that right there is why you don't want
to add too much flour to your dough
initially right it'll be too dense those
bubbles will be too small and you'll end
up with severe milk and cranny envy okay
and that of course brings us to the
final and ultimate test we have to toast
it and eat it with butter and jam which
is what I'm doing here and for recipe I
basically wing from something I just saw
on TV I thought this came out really
really good had a nice crunch was just
chewy enough and really had a nice
flavor so anyway that's it my version of
English muffins inspired by the model
bakery in Napa I don't often watch food
television but when I do I prefer shows
I can steal ideas from and share them
with you here so I really do hope you
give these a try head over to food
wishes comm for all the ingredient
amounts and more info as usual and as
always enjoy
you
